Program¶

modules.files_manager.csv_creator(writing_path_input, writing_input)¶

This function will create .csv files

Parameters

  • writing_path_input (string) – Path where the .csv file will be created

  • writing_input (TO BE DONE) – What info we want to add to the .csv file, normally a Matrix/Array 3D

modules.files_manager.csv_mixer(path_input1, path_input2, writing_path_input)¶

Mixes two .csv files. Then, uses csv_creator() to generate a .csv with the mixed files.

Parameters

  • path_input1 (string) – Path to the first .csv to mix. It will take the first rows in the final mixed file.

  • path_input2 (string) – Path to the second .csv to mix. It will take rows adther the first .csv.

  • writing_path_input (string) – path to both .csv files

modules.files_manager.fasta_creator(path_input, fasta_output_path)¶

HAY QUE MODIFICARLO, NECESITO QUE EL NUMERING SEA 01, 02, 03, 04…09, 10, 11. Y no como lo tengo ahora, que es 1, 2, 3, 4, 5…10, 11, 12.

modules.files_manager.folder_creator(options)¶

Creates a Folder in the current path

Paran options

Name of the folder

Returns

Folder in the current directory

modules.blaster.blastn_blaster(query_path, dict_path, outfile_path, perc_identity)¶

This module calls for blastn in the BLASTR command line. See Command Line Application User Manual for more information.

Parameters

  • query_path (string) – Path to our .fasta query used in BLASTn against our database.

  • dict_path (string) – Path to our database we made with blastn_dic().

  • outfile_path (string) – path where the results will be saved. Remember to write it with the .csv ending.

  • perc_identity (string) – Percent oh identity which we want to make the BLASTn

Returns

a .csv file with the results of the BLASTN

Return type

.csv file

Arguments used in blastn¶

Argument

Type

Description

-word_size

integer
28 by default.
BLAST search starts with finding a perfect sequence match of length given by this parameter.
See world_size info for more information.

-query

string

Query file name.

-db

string

BLAST database name.

-out

string

Output file name.

-perc_identity

integer

Percent identity cutoff.

-outfmt

string
Alignment view options. Written inside in a nested string.
Explained in Table
See Command Line Application User Manual and Metagenomics BLASTn manual for help.
Arguments used in --outfmt inside blastn¶

Argument

Description

10

Comma-separated values.

qseqid
Query Seq-id.
ID of our query sequence.

sseqid
Subject Seq-id.
ID of our subject sequence.

pident

Percentage of identical matches.

length

Alignment length.

qlen

Query sequence length.

slen

Subject sequence length.

mismatch

Number of mismatches.

gapopen

Number of gap openings.

qstart

Start of alignment in query.

qend

End of alignment in query.

sstart

Start of alignment in subject.

send

End of alignment in subject.

evalue

Expect value.

bitscore

Bit score.

sstrand

Subject strand.

sseq

Aligned part of subject sequence.
modules.blaster.blastn_dic(path_input)¶

Creation af a BLAST database of our whole genome. It uses the BLASTR command line, see BLAST Command Line Application User Manual for more information.

The generation of the properly database will be placed in the .fasta directory. It is recommended to use a dedicated folder to this genome.

Parameters

path_input (string) – path to where our file genome sequence .fasta is

modules.blaster.repetitive_blaster(genome_fasta, path_input, folder_path, naming_short, max_diff, numbering, maximun_runs)¶

This function will iterate till a number of maximun_runs defined.

Parameters

  • genome_fasta (string) – Path to our genome sequence in .fasta.

  • path_input (string) – Path to the .csv file where data will be filtered.

  • folder_path (string) – Path to a folder where the results will be placed. Subfolder will be created with the cromosome names.

  • naming_short (string) – Label needed to read the ID of each cromosome in the .csv file. In the case of L. infantum for example, would be LinJ since the .csv file IDs are LinJ.XX

  • max_diff (integer) – Maximun proxomity value for the different sequences when they have to be grouped. Important

  • numbering (integer) – Indicates the number showed for the first program run. If it’s 0, then, the first run will be name 0.

  • maximun_runs (integer) – Indicates the last iterative execution of function.

Warning

Pay special attention to the max_diff argument.

modules.identifiers.genome_specific_chromosome_main(path_input, chromosome_ID, main_folder_path, genome_fasta, naming_short, max_diff)¶
modules.identifiers.specific_sequence_extractor(path_input, chromosome_ID, main_folder_path)¶

First it reads a .csv file and takes the rows which include in the second column (the one with the chromosome IDs), the defined chromosome. Then, it creates a .csv file with all the selectes rows in a subfolder in a specified directory using folder_creator() and csv_creator().

Example of use

If chromosome_ID = LinJ.02, it will take all rows in the .csv where the second column contains LinJ.02

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path where the .csv file we’ll use to read and filter data is.

  • chromosome_ID (string) – Chromosome identifier, e.g., LinJ.07.

  • main_folder_path (string) – Path where the results will be placed. It will create a subfolder with the chromosome_ID name.

Returns

A .csv file with the selected “chromosome_ID”.

Return type

csv file

modules.seq_modifier.specific_sequence_1000nt(path_input, chromosome_ID, main_folder_path)¶

This function will expand the selected sequence to 1000 nt and will create a CSV file with it.

It uses the function csv_creator()

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path where the .csv file we’ll use to read and filter data is.

  • chromosome_ID (string) – Chromosome identifier, e.g., LinJ.07.

  • main_folder_path (string) – Path where the results will be placed. It will create a subfolder with the chromosome_ID name + “_1000nt.csv”.

Returns

a csv file with the sufix “_1000nt.csv”

Return type

CSV file

modules.seq_modifier.specific_sequence_corrected(path_input, nucleotides1000_directory, main_folder_path, chromosome_ID)¶

Danger

NEED TO MODIFY IT BECAUSE OF SOME ERRORS

The main use of this function is to get the real “coordinates” of the sequence.

Remember we’ve got first, after the initial BLASNn, sequence expanded to 1000nt. The next part of the program was launching them one against each other to get a BLASTn which can provide us useful information about the real coordinates:

Now we’ve got the 1000 nt sequences with an aproximade location of where the SIDER2 are. And then, we’ve got the BLASTn (of them against each other) which can provide us with the real coordinates.

With this, this function will get the real coordinates.

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path to the CSV file we’ll use to filter data. It’s the result from a BLASTn made between the expanded 1000nt sequences.

  • nucleotides1000_directory (string) – return result from the function specific_sequence_1000nt()

  • main_folder_path (string) – Path where we’ll save the CSV data file to.

  • chromosome_ID (string) – Identification of the cromosome, e.g., “LinJ.07”

Returns

Return type

modules.filters.filter_by_column(path_input, column, size_filter, writing_path_input)¶

This function will filter a CSV data depending on length (if we want to firlter by sequence length) or percent (if we want to filter by identity percent).

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path to the .csv file we want to filter data.

  • column (string) – Can be length (if we want to firlter by sequence length) or percent (if we want to filter by identity percent)

  • size_filter (integer) – Number to filter dependint of the column argument.

  • writing_path_input (string) – Path to the CSV file this function will create and save

Returns

A CSV file with the dalta filtered depending on the column and size_filter argumetns.

Return type

CSV file
